post.description:
Stream upload a build artifact directly to S3.

This endpoint handles the entire upload flow in one request:
1. Validates the app and version
2. Streams the file directly to S3 (memory-efficient for large files)
3. Extracts package ID from the artifact (Android package name or iOS bundle ID)
4. Creates the build record with the artifact URL and package info

Use this instead of upload-url + direct S3 upload when you want
a simpler single-request upload flow.

Create a build by fetching an artifact from a protected URL (e.g., EAS).

Behavior:
- Validates org ownership and mobile platform (service accounts bypass org check)
- Idempotent on (app_id, version): returns existing row if present
- Streams download, computes sha256, uploads to S3 under org prefix
- For tar/tar.gz files: extracts .app directory before uploading
- Persists builds row with artifact_url and merged metadata

Mark a build upload as complete and update metadata.

Note: artifact_url is now set in upload-url, so this endpoint
only updates metadata and package_name. It's optional but useful
for adding additional info after upload completes.

Extract package identifier from an uploaded build artifact for a specific version.
This can be called immediately after the browser finishes uploading the file,
before the client calls complete-upload. We locate the artifact in S3 by prefix.

post.description:
Copy a test and all its associated data to a target organization.

This is a privileged admin operation that copies:
- Test configuration and tasks
- Build variables and versions (if applicable)
- Referenced code execution scripts
- Environment variables (for mobile tests)
- Custom variables

Supports bidirectional cross-environment copying:
- source_from_other_env: Read source test from the other environment's database
  (staging if on prod, production if on staging)
- target_other_env: Write target test to the other environment's database
  (staging if on prod, production if on staging)
- target_org_id: Copy to any organization (defaults to benchmarks org)

Args:
    request: Contains the test_id to copy, optional new_name,
        source_from_other_env, target_other_env, and target_org_id.
    auth: Admin authentication info (injected by dependency).

Returns:
    CopyTestToBenchmarksResponse with details of what was copied.

Raises:
    HTTPException: If the test is not found or copy fails.

Note:
    Requires admin dashboard access permission.

post.description:
Copy a workflow and all its tests to a target organization.

This is a privileged admin operation that copies:
- All tests in the workflow (using TestCopyService)
- Workflow configuration and metadata
- Creates new workflow with mapped test IDs

If tests already exist in target org (detected by name pattern), they will
be resynced instead of duplicated.

Supports bidirectional cross-environment copying:
- source_from_other_env: Read source workflow from the other environment's database
  (staging if on prod, production if on staging)
- target_other_env: Write target workflow to the other environment's database
  (staging if on prod, production if on staging)
- target_org_id: Copy to any organization (defaults to benchmarks org)

Args:
    request: Contains the workflow_id to copy, optional new_name,
        source_from_other_env, target_other_env, and target_org_id.
    auth: Admin authentication info (injected by dependency).

Returns:
    CopyWorkflowToBenchmarksResponse with details of what was copied.

Raises:
    HTTPException: If the workflow is not found or copy fails.

Note:
    Requires admin dashboard access permission.

get.description:
Get the copy configuration for this environment.

Returns information about cross-environment copy capabilities:
- current_env_name: Name of the current environment ("staging" or "production")
- other_env_name: Name of the other environment that can be targeted
  ("staging", "production", or null if not configured)

This helps the frontend show/hide cross-environment copy options.

Args:
    auth: Admin authentication info (injected by dependency).

Returns:
    Dictionary with copy configuration.

get.description:
Get worker WebSocket connection info for a workflow run.

Frontend calls this after starting a device to get the direct
WebSocket URL for control messages.

Returns:
    - status="ready" with worker_ws_url when worker is available
    - status="not_ready" while worker is initializing
    - status="cancelled"/"stopped"/"failed" if session is terminated

Args:
    workflow_run_id: The workflow run ID to get connection info for.
    _auth: Authentication info (validated but not used directly).

Returns:
    WorkerConnectionResponse with status and optional worker_ws_url.

post.description: Start a device session and return task and websocket details.

Cancel an in-flight device Hatchet run.

Updates the device_sessions DB record to 'cancelled' and attempts to
cancel the Hatchet workflow run.  The Hatchet cancel is best-effort;
failures are logged and surfaced in the response via ``hatchet_cancelled``
but do not cause the endpoint to return an error (the DB update is the
critical part).

Args:
    workflow_run_id: The Hatchet workflow run ID to cancel.
    auth_info: Authenticated caller (injected by Depends).

Returns:
    JSON dict with ``success``, ``db_updated``, and ``hatchet_cancelled``.
Trigger a test execution asynchronously via Hatchet event.
Trigger multiple test executions asynchronously via Hatchet events.

Cancel a running test execution by task ID.

This endpoint:
1. Fetches the test execution status from the database
2. Checks if the test is already in a terminal state
3. Updates test_executions and device_sessions status to 'cancelled'
4. Cancels the Hatchet workflow run if one exists

Args:
    task_id: The test execution ID to cancel
    auth_info: Authentication info from the request

Returns:
    CancelTestResponse with success status and message

Raises:
    HTTPException: 404 if test not found, 500 on internal error
Execute a workflow by its ID asynchronously via Hatchet event push.

Cancel a running workflow and all its child tests.

This endpoint:
1. Fetches the workflow execution status from the database
2. Checks if the workflow is already in a terminal state
3. Updates workflow_executions status to 'cancelled'
4. Cancels all child test executions (cascade)
5. Cancels the Hatchet workflow run if one exists

Args:
    task_id: The workflow execution ID to cancel
    auth_info: Authentication info from the request

Returns:
    WorkflowCancelResponse with success status and message

Raises:
    HTTPException: 404 if workflow not found, 500 on internal error

status, and validation results for progress bar visualization.

Called by the CLI after workflow completion. Runs eval in the background
and sends a Slack alert if grounding errors are detected.

Requires god_mode permission.

patch.description:
Dismiss a step as a false positive.

Atomically updates the step in step_results JSONB and increments false_positive_count.
Requires god_mode permission.

Mark a step as annotated (after GroundingReportModal submission).

Atomically updates the step in step_results JSONB and increments annotated_count.
Requires god_mode permission.

Mark an eval result as fully reviewed.

Sets review_status='reviewed', reviewed_at=now(), reviewed_by=user_id.
Requires god_mode permission.

get.description:
Get running and queued Android task counts for KEDA scaling.

This endpoint is called by KEDA's metrics-api trigger to determine how
many Android worker pods should be running. It aggregates counts from
both durable (interactive/live session) and headless (test execution)
workflows.

Args:
    env: The environment to get task counts for (staging or production).
    auth_info: Authentication info (requires service or admin access).

Returns:
    AndroidTaskCountResponse: Task counts broken down by workflow type.

Raises:
    HTTPException: If auth fails or there's an error fetching counts.

Get all system apps for both iOS and Android platforms.

Returns:
    AllSystemAppsResponse: System apps for both platforms.

Get system apps for a specific platform.

Args:
    platform: Platform identifier ('ios' or 'android').

Returns:
    SystemAppsResponse: System apps for the specified platform.

Raises:
    HTTPException: If platform is not 'ios' or 'android'.

Test endpoint to verify OpenTelemetry tracing and log correlation is working.
Returns the current trace ID if tracing is active.

This endpoint demonstrates:
- Trace/span ID capture
- Semantic conventions usage

- Execution context propagation

ssm_instance_id.description: AWS SSM managed instance ID for remote command execution

FleetSandbox.title: FleetSandbox
FleetSandbox.description:
Represents a virtual machine sandbox in the Fleet pool.

Sandboxes are Mac Mini VMs that developers can claim for development work.
Each sandbox can host multiple git repositories and worktrees.

Attributes:
    id: Unique identifier for the sandbox (UUID).
    org_id: Organization ID that owns this sandbox (NULL = shared pool).
    vm_name: VM name (e.g., "sandbox-1").
    hostname: Human-readable hostname for display.
    sandbox_type: Type of sandbox (dedicated machine or container).
    host_identifier: Groups sandboxes running on the same physical host.
    tunnel_hostname: Cloudflare tunnel hostname for SSH access.
    status: Current sandbox state (available, claimed, maintenance, reserved).
    claimed_by: User ID of the developer who claimed this sandbox.
    claimed_at: Timestamp when the sandbox was claimed.
    ssh_user: SSH username for connections (default: revyl-admin).
    ssh_port: SSH port number (default: 22).
    specs: Hardware specifications (cpu_cores, memory_gb, chip).
    tags: Flexible labels for filtering (location, tier, etc.).
    created_at: When the sandbox was added to the pool.
    updated_at: Last modification timestamp.

FleetTunnel.title: FleetTunnel
FleetTunnel.description:
Represents an active Cloudflare tunnel on a sandbox.

Tunnels provide temporary public URLs for accessing services
running on sandboxes (e.g., frontend dev server, API).

Attributes:
    port: Local port being tunneled.
    url: Public Cloudflare tunnel URL.
    pid: Process ID of the cloudflared process.
    branch: Optional worktree branch associated with this tunnel.
    sandbox_name: Name of the sandbox hosting this tunnel.
    service_name: Human-readable service name (e.g., "frontend", "backend").

FleetWorktree.title: FleetWorktree
FleetWorktree.description:
Represents a git worktree on a Fleet sandbox.

Worktrees allow multiple branches to be checked out simultaneously
on the same sandbox, enabling parallel development work.

Attributes:
    branch: Git branch name for this worktree.
    path: Filesystem path on the sandbox.
    is_main: Whether this is the main/primary worktree.
    repo: Repository name (e.g., "cognisim-monorepo").
    sandbox_name: Name of the sandbox hosting this worktree.
    sandbox_id: UUID of the sandbox hosting this worktree.
    branched_from: Base branch this worktree was created from.
    created_at: When the worktree was created.

RegisterSandboxRequest.title: RegisterSandboxRequest
RegisterSandboxRequest.description:
Request payload for registering (upserting) a sandbox during provisioning.

Called by the fleet CLI or Ansible playbook after provisioning a Mac.
Upserts into fleet_sandboxes by vm_name so the sandbox is discoverable
by the developer CLI and FleetDashboard.

Attributes:
    vm_name: Unique VM name (e.g., "Revyl-Mac-mini-W641QMFKQR").
    hostname: mDNS hostname (e.g., "Revyl-Mac-mini-W641QMFKQR.local").
    org_id: Organization ID to reserve this sandbox for. If set, only
        users from this org can claim it. NULL means shared pool.
    tunnel_hostname: Cloudflare tunnel hostname for SSH access.
    ssh_user: SSH username for connections (default: revyl-admin).
    ssh_port: SSH port number (default: 22).
    status: Initial sandbox status (default: available).
    specs: Hardware specifications (cpu_cores, memory_gb, chip).
    tags: Flexible labels for filtering (location, tier, etc.).
    db_env: Target database environment override. When set, the backend
        routes the registration to the specified Supabase instance
        instead of the backend's default. Use "staging" for internal
        sandboxes and "production" for external/customer sandboxes.

created.title: Created

RegisterSandboxResponse.description:

RunningTestMetadataContent.title: RunningTestMetadataContent
RunningTestMetadataContent.description:
Typed metadata content for running tests (partial reports).

This model provides structured fields for the metadata_content when a test
is still in progress. It shares a common interface with ReportView (used for
completed tests) to ensure consistent frontend consumption.

Common fields with ReportView:
    - test_name, test_id, platform: Test identification
    - success: Test result (None = in-progress, True/False = completed)
    - steps_data: Step execution data
    - run_config: LLM and execution configuration
    - device_metadata: Device screen size, type, runtime
    - run_id: OpenTelemetry trace ID for correlation
    - workflow_run_id: Hatchet workflow ID (if part of workflow)

Running-test specific fields:
    - _partial: Always True for running tests
    - _upload_status: Upload progress information
    - core_info: Nested test identification (for backwards compatibility)

status.title: Status
status.description: Status indicating test is still running

    workflow_id: UUID of the workflow to execute.
    run_config: Optional run configuration override for workflow-triggered tests.
    build_config: Optional build configuration override for this execution.
    override_build_config: When True with build_config, overrides test builds.
